text.p: These are the leading stories in Pakistani newspapers on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
DAWN

- The government will pay a compensation of 100,000 rupees each to the victims of the poisonous gas leakage in the Punjab province capital of Lahore, while two companies will pay 200,000 rupees each to the dependants of those who died after inhaling the gas.
- The Election Commission will set up more than 9,000 new polling stations in Pakistan for the February 3 general elections.
- Unidentified assailants shot dead an activist of Sipah-i-Sahaba Pakistan, a Sunni militant organisation, who was in hospital in Lahore city for the treatment of an earlier shooting wound.

- The interior ministry has received 223 cases of alleged corruption and misuse of authority against politicians, bureaucrats and other influentials from different government departments for accountability.
- As many as 13 human rights organisations have announced that they will mobilise public opinion and campaign against the newly formed Council for Defence and National Security.
- Sita White, the lady who has filed a case against Imran Khan in Los Angeles to establish the fatherhood of her daughter, says she is not planing to go to Pakistan soon.

- Despite the renewal of the IMF standby arrangement and the release of a $77 million tranche, Pakistan's risk rating continues to be very low and its borrowing ability in the international market has not improved.
THE NEWS

- Supreme Court chief justice Sajjad Ali Shah told reporters in Lahore on Friday that the writ petition filed by deposed prime minister Benazir Bhutto for the restoration of her government would be decided on merit before the February 3 elections.
THE NATION
- The law and order arrangements for February 3 elections are being handed over to the army from Saturday, Defence Minister Shahid Hamid told reporters in Lahore on Friday.
- The garment-manufacturing industry is facing severe crises and 1,400 out of 2,000 units have already been closed.
BUSINESS RECORDER
- Pakistan's foreign exchange reserves bounced back to the level of around $800 million at the weekend.
- Prime Minister Meraj Khalid and his British counterpart John Major will inaugurate the "Pak-U.K. Investment 2000 Seminar" on January 14 in Lahore.
THE FRONTIER POST
- Caretaker prime minister Meraj Khalid said his government has saved the economy from bankruptcy.
--Islamabad newsroom 9251-274757
